title: 109_s2475
content: The Act titled "Commission to Study the Potential Creation of a National Museum of the American Latino Community Act of 2006" establishes a commission. The Commission to Study the Potential Creation of a National Museum of the American Latino Community consists of 23 members appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, minority leader of the House, majority leader of the Senate, and minority leader of the Senate. Voting and nonvoting members are included in the Commission. The Commission to Study the Potential Creation of a National Museum of the American Latino Community appoints 1 nonvoting member. Members must have a commitment to American Latino life, art, history, and culture, along with expertise in museum administration, fundraising, Latino culture and history, Smithsonian representation, or public service. The Commission appoints 1 nonvoting member with expertise in museum administration, fundraising, Latino culture, history, or public service. The Commission appoints 1 nonvoting member with expertise in museum administration, fundraising, Latino culture, history, or public service to assist with its functions. The Commission will submit a report to the President and Congress with recommendations for establishing and maintaining a National Museum of the American Latino Community in Washington, DC. They will develop fundraising plans and examine issues such as collection availability and the Museum's impact on the Hispanic community. The Commission will consider possible locations for the National Museum of the American Latino Community in Washington, DC, its governance structure, and community engagement in the museum's development. Legislation will be proposed based on the recommendations in the report for Congressional consideration. The Commission will convene a national conference on the Museum, involving individuals dedicated to American Latino life, art, history, and culture, within 9 months of the Act's enactment. SEC. 4. ADMINISTRATIVE PROVISIONS. The Secretary of the Interior will provide facilities, support, and funds for the Commission. Members not federal employees may receive compensation and travel expenses. The Commission must submit final reports within 18 months of the Act's enactment and terminate within 30 days of submission. $2.1 million is authorized for 2007 and $1.1 million for 2008.
